Fig. 2 Representative TEM images of N-ZSM-22 at (a) low- and (b) high- resolution. Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the (a) Ni (PDF#04–0850, ♦), (b) 0.5Ni/N-ZSM-22, (c) 1.0Ni/N-ZSM-22, (d) 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22, and (e) 6.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalysts. School of Petrochemical Engineering Changzhou University Changzhou Jiangsu 213164 China Graphical abstract The catalytic conversion of biomass-derived fatty acids into iso-alkanes is a promising approach for producing high-quality renewable biofuels. Herein, Ni catalysts on nanocrystal ZSM-22 (xNi/N-ZSM-22, x represents Ni loading) featuring an abundance of mesoporous structure and numerous accessible 10-member ring (10-MR) openings are prepared, and then tested for converting palmitic acid into long-chain iso-alkanes through a single-step process involving deoxygenation and hydroisomerization reactions. The catalyst with a Ni loading of 3.0 wt% (3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22) demonstrated the highest intrinsic reaction rate (13.6 × 10−4 mol·g−1·h−1) and TOF (14.2 h−1) among xNi/N-ZSM-22 catalysts. This catalyst also exhibited optimal iso-alkanes selectivity of 81.8 % (iso-hexadecanes and iso-pentadecanes), which can be attributed to the efficient synergy between the acid and metal functions. In comparison to a Ni catalyst on conventional ZSM-22 (58.4 %), the superior isomerization selectivity (81.8 %) of the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 is closely related to its abundant mesoporous structure and more accessible 10-MR openings. Moreover, ketonization was identified as a significant pathway for palmitic acid deoxygenation based on kinetic analysis. Keywords Ni catalyst ZSM-22 Deoxygenation Hydroisomerization Palmitic acid Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction The emerging biofuels, including biodiesel and bio-jet fuel, have attracted significant attention as a vital component of biomass energy, owing to their striking similarity to conventional fossil fuels, thereby rendering as a promising substitute for fossil fuels [1–3]. Meanwhile, developing biofuel is also considered an effective approach to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, a major greenhouse gas that contributes to global warming. Fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs) has been categorized as the 1st-generation biofuel, derived from inedible vegetable or microalga oils by transesterification reaction with methanol [4–6], which is relatively mature and has achieved large-scale production in the worldwide due to its reproducibility and environmental benignity [7,8]. However, FAMEs suffer from several limitations, including high oxygen content, low heating value, poor low-temperature fluidity, and limited miscibility with fossil fuels [7,8]. To realize the complete replacing fossil fuels with biofuels, they require a two-step hydrotreating process, comprising deoxygenation and hydroisomerization, which aim to remove oxygen and improve the cold flow properties of the resulting biofuel, respectively [9–11]. However, this method is limited by its complicated operation process and high manufacturing costs. Consequently, it is of great significance to integrate the deoxygenation and hydroisomerization processes into a single step, which can be more economical and attractive [12–14]. Nonetheless, achieving high efficiency deoxygenation while maintaining high selectivity for long-chain iso-alkanes is still a challenge. It is well-known that deoxygenation of various long-chain fatty acids (C16–C22), particularly stearic acid and palmitic acid, has been extensively studied [7,8,15–18]. This type of reaction primarily occurs on supported metal catalysts such as Pt, Pd, and Ni, owing to their superior hydrogenation ability. On these types of catalysts, the metal active sites facilitate the hydrogenolysis of C-O bonds in fatty acids, resulting in the cleavage of C-O bonds and the formation of alkanes [7,8,15]; the acid sites on the catalyst support promote the dehydration of intermediate products, such as fatty alcohols, to form alkenes, which are further hydrogenated to alkanes at the metal sites [7,8,15]. In contrast, the hydroisomerization of long-chain n-alkanes to isomerized alkanes occurs on noble Pt catalysts supported on acidic zeolite, known as bifunctional catalysts [19]. On these types of catalysts, the metal sites catalyze the dehydrogenation of normal alkanes to form alkene intermediates, which are further converted to isomerized alkenes at the B acid sites, and then hydrogenated to isomerized alkanes at the adjacent metal sites [19–21]. To reduce catalyst cost, transition metal Ni is usually preferred to replace Pt due to its superior hydrogenation ability among the non-noble catalysts [17,22,23]. Based on the above analysis, it is possible to achieve the integration of the deoxygenation and hydroisomerization on a single catalyst by selecting a suitable support such as acidic zeolite [10,12,24]. Moreover, it is important to highlight that this catalyst should demonstrate not only exceptional deoxygenation capability, but also remarkable isomerization selectivity, leading to high yields of long-chain iso-alkanes, a critical requirement for converting fatty acids into high-quality biofuels. Acidic zeolites characterized by one-dimensional channel and 10-membered rings (10-MR), such as ZSM-22, ZSM-23, and SAPO-11, are particularly well-suited for the formation of branched isomers in the long-chain n-alkanes hydroisomerization reaction, due to the pore-selective catalysis of these zeolites [25–27]. Inspired by this, it is conceivable that metal catalysts on these types of zeolites would generate more iso-alkanes components during the hydrotreatment process for the long-chain fatty acids conversion. It has also been proved that acidic ZSM-22 or SAPO-11 zeolite supported metal catalysts (Co [28], Ni [29], Mo [30], and PtSn [9]) exhibited relatively high long-chain iso-alkanes selectivity (40 ∼ 63 %) for the one-step deoxygenation and hydroisomerization reaction of fatty acids. However, normal alkanes still predominate in the liquid products, failing to meet fuel standards. Additionally, a considerable quantity of cracking by-products are consistently produced, reducing the yield of long-chain iso-alkanes. This is because conventional zeolites, such as ZSM-22, have a limited number of available 10-MR openings, which is responsible for the protonation and the selective skeletal rearrangement for the alkene intermediates, termed as pore mouth catalysis [31]. At the same time, diffusion limitation leads to undesirable cracking [32]. Therefore, it is reasonable to utilize mesostructured or nano-sized zeolites to design a catalyst for the one-step deoxygenation and hydroisomerization of fatty acids to achieve the production of iso-alkanes in high selectivity. In this work, nanocrystal ZSM-22 zeolite (N-ZSM-22), featuring an abundance of mesoporous structure and numerous accessible 10-member ring (10-MR) openings, was utilized to prepare a series of Ni catalysts that boost the single-step deoxygenation-hydroisomerization of palmitic acid (C15H31COOH) to produce iso-alkanes with high selectivity. The results demonstrated that the N-ZSM-22 supported Ni catalyst (Ni/N-ZSM-22) showed good catalytic activity for palmitic acid conversion. Notably, the Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst with a loading of 3.0 wt% exhibited a high selectivity of 81.8 % for long-chain iso-alkanes (C15 + C16), significantly outperforming the isomerization performance for long-chain alkanes (48 ∼ 62.7 %) reported in previous literatures. The Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst with high isomerization selectivity for the one-step conversion of the C15H31COOH was discussed. Ketonization of palmitic acid significantly contributes to the deoxygenation of C15H31COOH based on the kinetic analysis. This work provides a strategy for preparing Ni multifunctional catalysts for one-step deoxygenation-hydroisomerization of fatty acids. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Silica sol (SiO2, 30.5 wt%) was provided by Zhejiang Yuda Chemical Co. Ltd. Nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O), potassium hydroxide (KOH), aluminum sulfate (Al2(SO4)3⋅18H2O) were got from Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. 1,6-diaminohexane (DAH) and palmitic acid (97.0 %) were purchased from Shanghai Maclean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Cyclohexane (>99.7 %) was purchased from Shanghai Titan Technology Co., Ltd. All the reagents were used without further purification. 2.2 Zeolite synthesis Nanocrystal ZSM-22 zeolite was synthesized according to a previous literature [33], using a gel with a molar composition of 1.0Al2O3/16.5K2O/41.4DAH/109SiO2/4584H2O. And cationic copolymer (COPQA) was used as mesoporous template. Briefly, 0.22 g of Al2(SO4)3⋅18H2O, 0.61 g of KOH, and 20.0 mL of H2O were mixed in a beaker, followed by stirring at room temperature for 30 min., Then, a solution containing 1.59 g of DAH and 2.16 g of COPQA was dropped slowly into the beaker, followed by adding 7.19 g of silica sol under vigorous stirring. After stirred for 60 min, the obtained gel was dynamically crystallized at 160 °C for 72 h. Then, the crystallization product was filtered, washed, dried at 100 °C overnight, and calcined in air at 550 °C for 10 h. Subsequently, the parent nanocrystalline ZSM-22 was pretreated in 1 M nitric acid solution at 95 °C for 3 h, followed by washing, dried at 100 °C, and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. Finally, the treated nanocrystalline ZSM-22 zeolite was denoted as N-ZSM-22. For comparison, a conventional microporous ZSM-22 zeolite with needle-shape was synthesized in the absence of COPQA, and pretreated by the same method above. The final sample obtained was denoted as C-ZSM-22. 2.3 Catalyst preparation Ni catalysts on N-ZSM-22 zeolite were prepared by an initial wetness impregnation method. After impregnating the N-ZSM-22 with a solution containing required amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, the catalyst sample was left at room temperature for 8 h, and then dried at 100 °C overnight. Subsequently, the dried catalyst sample was tableted under a pressure of 6.0 MPa, and sieved into 20–40 mesh, followed by calcination at 450°C for 4 h. The Ni loadings were set to 0.5, 1.0, 3.0, and 6.0, respectively. The obtained catalysts were denoted as xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5, 1.0, 3.0, and 6.0), where x stand for the Ni loading. For comparison, a Ni catalyst supported on conventional needle-shaped ZSM-22 was also prepared by the same method, and denoted as 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22, where the numeral ‘3.0ʼ represents the Ni loading. 2.4 Characterization XRD analysis was conducted using RIGAKU Ultima IV diffractometer equipped with X-ray source generating Cu Ka radiation (λ = 0.154059 nm) at 40 KV and 150 mA. The value range of diffraction angle of diffractometer is 2θ = 5–50°. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image was taken with a SUPRA55 instrument. Prior to taking an image, the sample needs to undergo gold spraying treatment. The contents of Ni were measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) with Agilent 5110 instrument. N2 physisorption of the samples was measured by Micromeritics 2020 instrument. Samples were pretreated by degassing at 300 °C for 4 h and analyzed at liquid nitrogen temperature(−196 °C). The micropore surface area, micropore volume and mesopore surface area were determined by t-plot method, and the total surface area was calculated by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation. The Ni particle size was measured by static CO chemisorption using the same instrument. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image was taken with a JEM-2100 instrument with a line resolution of 1.4 Å, operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Before analysis, the freshly reduced sample powder was dispersed in absolute ethanol and then ultrasonically treated for 10 min, followed by dropping onto a carbon membrane-coated Cu grid. The acidic properties of the samples were characterized by ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy of 2,6-dimethylpyridine (DMPy-IR). NH3-TPD experiment was performed using a Micromeritics ASAP 2920 instrument. 150 mg of calcined sample loaded into a sample tube was pre-treated in a He gas flow at 550 °C for 1 h. After cooling to 120 °C, the sample was purged with 10 mol. %NH3-He mixed gas for 0.5 h. Then, the sample was treated with a He stream at 120 °C for 2 h to remove physically adsorbed NH3, and subsequently heated to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/ min in the He stream. The desorbed NH3 was detected by thermal conductivity detector. In-situ DMPy-IR experiments were conducted on a Bruker Frontier (TENSOR 27) instrument. Thin self-supporting wafers (∼20 mg) of the sample powder were degassed at 400 °C for 1 h. After cooling to 50 °C, DMPy vapor was adsorbed for 20 min. The wafers were then vacuumed at 200 °C for 30 min before the DMPy-IR spectra were recorded. Temperature-programmed reduction by H2 was performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2920 instrument. 0.1 g of calcined sample was charged into the sample tube, and then heated to 700°C in the mixed 10.0 mol.%H2-Ar flow, with a rate of 10°C/min. The consumed H2 was recorded by a thermal conductivity detector. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was obtained using ESCALAB MK II system. The catalyst sample was first reduced at 400 °C for 2 h in the H2 flow (60 mL/min), and then transferred into a bottle containing cyclohexane under a continuous flow of H2 after cooling to room temperature. Prior to XPS experiments, the cyclohexane solvent was removed, and the residue was quickly transferred to the analysis chamber. After vacuuming at 1 × 10−4 Pa for 1 h, the XPS spectroscopy was obtained and calibrated by the C 1 s (284.8 eV). Thermogravimetric(TG) analysis was carried out on STA6000 instrument (PerkinElmer) to identify the carbon deposition on the used catalysts. About 6.0 mg sample was heated from room temperature to 800 °C by a heating rate of 10 °C/min under dry air flow (30 mL/min). 2.5 Activity test The catalytic deoxygenation and hydroisomerization performance of the prepared Ni catalysts for Palmitic acid (C15H31COOH) was performed on a home-made fixed bed reactor, with an inner diameter of 8.0 mm and a length of 600.0 mm. Firstly, 0.3 g (0.425–0.850 mm) of calcined catalyst was fully mixed with 1.0 g of SiC (0.425–0.850 mm), and loaded into the constant temperature zone. Then, the catalyst was heated to 400 °C under H2 flow (60 mL/min) at a heating rate of 2 °C/min., and kept at this temperature for 4 h. Finally, the catalytic performance was carried out at a pressure of 2.0 Mpa, an H2 flow of 30 mL/min., a reaction temperature of 240-290°C, a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 0.1 h−1, and a liquid feed of 1.0 wt% C15H31COOH in cyclohexane. Product liquid and exhaust gas were analyzed separately using an Agilent 7890B GC. The liquid phase was analyzed using a flame ionization detector and an HP-5 capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm), while the gas phase was analyzed using a thermal conductivity detector and an HP Plot-Q capillary column (30 m × 0.53 mm × 40 μm). The products were further identified on a gas chromatography mass spectrometer (GC–MS, Agilent 5977B Mass Selective Detector). C15H31COOH conversion and the iso-alkanes selectivity including iso-hexadecanes (iso-C16) and iso-pentadecanes (iso-C15) were calculated as follows: Conversion = moles of palmitic feed - (moles of palmitic) effluent moles of palmitic feed × 100% Isomer selectivity = iso -alkanes effluent Conversion × 100% Furthermore, the intrinsic catalytic activity was investigated after ruling out the mass transfer limitations, which is verified by Weisz–Prater (C WP) and Mears (C M) criteria. A detailed calculation was provided in supporting information. The observed reaction rate (r obs) for C15H31COOH conversion were determined using the following equation: r obs = dx d ( W / F ) The turnover frequency of the C15H31COOH (TOF, h−1) were calculated using the equation T OF= r obs M × 10 - 6 where F is the reactant molar flow (mol·h−1), x is the C15H31COOH conversion (%), and W is the loaded catalyst mass (g). M is the number of moles of loaded Ni sites, determined by the CO uptakes (μmol·g−1). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization Fig. 1 a displays the XRD pattern of the synthesized N-ZSM-22, which exhibits the typical diffraction peaks associated with the TON topological structure in the 5-50° range [34]. The N2 sorption isotherm of N-ZSM-22, shown in Fig. 1 b, has a hysteresis loop at a relative pressure of 0.45–0.96, indicating that the N-ZSM-22 contains a mesoporous structure. The corresponding mesopore size distribution of N-ZSM-22 is primarily centered at 28.6 nm (inset in Fig. 1 b). The TEM image reveals that the length of N-ZSM-22 along the [001] direction is significantly reduced, and the mesopore structure was mainly derived from the interstitial nanopores among these assembled shortened ZSM-22 nanorods (Fig. 2 a). Moreover, structural defects are observed on some of these shortened nanorods. The TEM results provide direct evidence for the presence of a sufficient number of hierarchical mesopores in the N-ZSM-22 nanocrystals (Fig. 2), which not only restricts cracking by improving molecule diffusion but also enhances the isomerization activity by increasing the available 10-MR openings. In addition, a conventional ZSM-22 (C-ZSM-22) was synthesized and verified by XRD ( Fig. S1 ), exhibiting a needle-shaped morphology, as confirmed by the SEM image ( Fig. S2 ). A detailed comparison on the structural features between the N-ZSM-22 and C-ZSM-22 has been discussed in a previous literature [33]. Consequently, in contrast to the needle-shaped C-ZSM-22 zeolite, the nanocrystal N-ZSM-22 assemblies feature an abundance of mesoporous structure and a large number of accessible 10-MR openings. Table 1 presents the detailed textural properties of the ZSM-22 supports and their supported Ni catalysts. Notably, the N-ZSM-22 exhibits a specific surface area of 271 m2/g, an external surface area of 143 m2/g, and a mesoporous volume of 0.43 cm3/g, higher than those of the C-ZSM-22 sample (240 m2/g, 26 m2/g, and 0.12 cm3/g, respectively). After loading of Ni precursors and reduction, the N-ZSM-22-supported Ni catalysts show a decrease in textural parameters compared to the N-ZSM-22 support. It should be pointed out that the decrease in microporous volume implies that partial Ni species penetrated into the micropore channel of the N-ZSM-22-based catalysts, blocking the micropore mouth to some degree, which is consistent with previous literatures [35,36]. Additionally, the actual loadings of Ni in these catalysts were nearly to the nominal values. The XRD results of the reduced xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) catalysts are presented in Fig. 3 . All the reduced catalysts exhibit typical diffraction peaks associated with the TON framework structure, indicating that the ZSM-22 zeolite structure is well-maintained in these treated catalysts. However, a distinct characteristic diffraction peak at 44.5°, assigned to the Ni phase (PDF#04–0850), is detected for the 6.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst, although this peak overlaps with N-ZSM-22 diffraction peak at 44.8°. Furthermore, it is observed that the intensity ratio of (402)/(152) for the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst is slightly higher than that for the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5 and 1.0) catalysts, both of which are similar to that of the pure N-ZSM-22 support (inset Fig. 3). These results suggest that smaller Ni particles are formed on the two xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5 and 1.0). catalysts, and the particle size gradually increase for the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 3.0 and 6.0) catalysts with increasing Ni loading. In addition, a similar result is also obtained for the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst with a small diffraction peak for the Ni phase ( Fig. S1 ). Fig. 4 displays the H2-TPR curves of the calcined xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 samples, providing insights into the interaction between the Ni species and the ZSM-22 support. Only one reduction peak is detected at 435 °C for the 0.5Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst, indicating that the Ni species are mainly distributed at the 10-MR pore mouths, resulting in a stronger interaction between the Ni and N-ZSM-22 [37,38]. As the Ni loading increases, different reduction behaviors of Ni oxides were observed in the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 1.0–6.0) catalysts. In addition to the reduction peak at the higher 435 °C, another reduction peak appears at around 325 °C, which can be attributed to the bulk NiO phase on the catalyst surface [6]. The proportion of low-temperature H2 consumption peak gradually increases with the increase of Ni loading for the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 1.0–6.0) catalysts, suggesting that more bulk NiOx are formed with the increasing Ni loading in the calcined catalysts, In addition, the H2-TPR profile for the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst reveals that the reduction peak in the low-temperature range is predominantly observed, implying that more bulk NiOx are formed on the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 than on the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22. This result is due to the fact that the N-ZSM-22 with shortened nanorods has a much higher mesoporous surface area than the long, needle-shaped C-ZSM-22, resulting in more exposure of the accessible 10-MR openings. In this case, more Ni oxides anchor at the 10-MR pore mouths for the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22, yielding a relatively strong interaction between Ni species and N-ZSM-22. To analyze the electronic state of the Ni species, XPS experiments are performed on these reduced Ni catalysts. Fig. 5 presents the fitted XPS spectra of Ni 2p 3/2 for the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 1.0–6.0) and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalysts according to the literatures [39–41]. Some Ni2+ species were detected on these Ni catalysts, with a binding energy at 854.7 ∼ 857.4 eV [42,43], which was due to the quick oxidation of the surface Ni0 species during the sample transfer [44]. Due to the low Ni loading, the 0.5Ni/N-ZSM-22 exhibits a poor signal-to-noise ratio, and its XPS data is not provided. It has been demonstrated that the Ni 2p 3/2 region for NiO phase could be deconvolved into two peaks at 853.8 ± 0.2 and 855.4 ± 0.2 eV, respectively, which can be explained in terms of a simplified model of final state effects in which photoemission is potentially accompanied by rearrangement of electrons in the valence band [45,46]. They can shift to higher binding energies (854.3 ± 0.2 and 856.1 ± 0.2 eV) for zeolite supported-Ni catalyst due to the NiO-support interaction. On the other hand, the Ni species on zeolite could also be present as the Ni − OH, with its binding energy of 856.5 eV [41]. As shown in Fig. 5, The binding energies at 854.5 ± 0.2 eV and 856.5 ± 0.2 eV were likely to be the mixture of the Ni-OH and NiO species [41]. The binding energy at 852.5 ± 0.2 eV corresponded to Ni0 species [47,48]. A comparison of the binding energy of Ni0 species on the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 1.0–6.0) and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalysts suggested that the 1.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 had a little higher binding energy of Ni0 species than the other two catalysts. This phenomenon can be attributed to the interaction strengthen of Ni species with N-ZSM-22 zeolite. The H2-TPR results suggested that a stronger interaction between NiOx and N-ZSM-22 on the 1.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst than the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 3.0 and 6.0) catalysts, leading to the stronger influence of the N-ZSM-22 on the smaller Ni species. A similar phenomenon was also observed for Ni catalysts on zeolite Beta due to the varied Ni-support interaction strengthen at different loadings [36]. Surface Ni species distribution and surface Ni/Si + Al ratios on these xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 1.0––6.0) and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalysts are listed in Table 2 . Compared to the xNi/N-ZSM-22 catalyst, the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst has a higher Ni/Si + Al ratio (0.040), possibly due to the larger external surface area of the N-ZSM-22 support, which facilitated the dispersion of the loaded Ni species. The acidic properties of the ZSM-22 and supported Ni catalysts were measured by NH3-TPD experiments, and the obtained results are shown in Fig. 6 a. The xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) catalysts exhibit two desorption peaks of NH3 at approximately 182 and 339 °C, corresponding to weak and strong acidic sites, respectively [49,50]. While their NH3-TPD profiles are similar to that of the pure N-ZSM-22 support ( Fig. S3 ), Table 3 reveals a significant change in their acidic concentration. After loading Ni, the total acidic concentration was 125.7 μmol/g for 0.5Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst, 128.2 μmol/g for 1.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst, 111.5 μmol/g for 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst, and 115.5 μmol/g for 6.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst. Compared to the pure N-ZSM-22 support, both the strong and weak acidic sites are significantly increased after loading Ni species. It has been reported that new strong acid sites can be produced by the interaction between Ni and zeolite ZSM-5 [51]. This may explain that the formation of more strong acidic sites on these supported Ni catalysts. On the other hand, the surface Ni species can act as Lewis acidic sites [40], leading to an increase in the acidic sites for these xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) catalysts. Similar results were also observed between the C-ZSM-22 and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 samples (Fig. 6 a and S3 ). It is noted that the C-ZSM-22 has a much stronger acidic strengthen and higher acidic concentration than the N-ZSM-22 (231.3 vs 99.4 μmol/g). This could be due to a good crystallinity of the C-ZSM-22, maintaining a relatively perfect TON framework structure, whereas the N-ZSM-22 was rich in structural defects, with less crystallinity, which was supported by the XRD and N2 sorption results. The C-ZSM-22 exhibits higher crystallinity and microporous surface area than the N-ZSM-22. The deoxygenation-hydroisomerization reaction of the long-chain fatty acid molecules mainly occurred on the pore mouth and external surface of the supported metal catalyst due to their large molecular size. Thus, the acidic sites located on the pore mouth and external surface of the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalysts were further studied by the in situ IR of the adsorbed DMPy (DMPy-IR) [33,52]. As shown in Fig. 6 b, all these catalysts samples exhibited a absorption band at ∼ 1640 cm−1, which was attributed DMPy adsorption on the Brønsted (B) acid sites. The calculated concentration of B acid sites was listed in Table 3 according to the method reported in previous studies [33,52]. And the 6.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst had the smallest acid concentration in these catalysts. The introduction of increased Ni loadings onto N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) catalysts causes a concomitant reduction in the accessibility of surface B acid sites, due to interactions between the loaded Ni and the acidic sites. Compared with the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22, the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 had lower B acidic sites due to its lower external surface area and available10-MR openings (24.2 vs 12.2 μmol·g−1), as discussed above. To obtain the information on Ni particle size in the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalysts, TEM experiments were performed on these catalysts. The obtained TEM images of the reduced xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalysts are presented in Fig. 7 . The images reveal that the formed Ni particles are well-dispersed on the external surface of the N-ZSM-22 zeolite. Notably, the size of the Ni particles in the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) catalysts increases gradually with increasing Ni loading. At higher Ni loadings, more Ni species tend to aggregate into larger NiOx particles due to the weaker interaction between Ni species and N-ZSM-22, as shown in Fig. 4 . After reduction by H2, these large NiOx are transformed into large Ni particles. This observation is consistent with the XRD results, which detected a characteristic diffraction peak associated with the Ni phase for the two xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 3.0, and 6.0) catalysts. In addition, a comparison of the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalysts reveals that the latter exhibits larger Ni particle size, which can be attributed to the lower external surface area of the C-ZSM-22 (Table 1), resulting in the aggregation of the Ni species. Static CO chemisorption was used to characterize the average Ni particle size and accessible Ni active sites, and these results are presented in Table 4 . The average Ni particle size increases in the following order: 0.5Ni/N-ZSM-22 (2.67 nm) < 1.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 (3.17 nm) < 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 (5.41 nm) < 6.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 (10.35 nm), consistent with the TEM results, implying the decrease in Ni dispersion. Correspondingly, the surface concentration of Ni active sites increases with increasing Ni loading for xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–3.0), from 30.7 to 57.9, to 95.9 μmol/g. However, further increasing the Ni loading to 6.0 wt% (99.7 μmol/g) leads to a slight increase in the Ni active site due to the aggregation of the loaded Ni species. Combined with the DMPy-IR results, the metal-to-acid ratio (CNi/CH + ) was calculated to evaluate the metal–acid balance for these supported Ni catalysts, and the data are listed in Table 4. The obtained CNi/CH + values over these xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) catalysts exhibits a gradual increase in increasing the Ni loading shape, with the largest CNi/CH + value for 6.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst (10.2). The 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst had a larger CNi/CH + value of 6.3 than the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst (4.6), suggesting an insufficient acid function for the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst. The different metal-to-acid ratios for these supported Ni catalysts could influence the deoxygenation-hydroisomerization performance in the C15H31COOH conversion, as discussed below. 3.2 Catalytic performance C15H31COOH is employed as a model compound of long-chain fatty acids to assess the catalytic coupling performance of deoxygenation and hydroisomerization reactions, given its prominence as a major product during the lipa conversion process. It is well-established that the deoxygenation of fatty acid proceeds through decarbonylation, decarboxylation, and hydrodeoxygenation reactions. The former two pathways yield n-pentadecane (n-C15) with a single carbon atom loss, whereas the latter pathway produces n-hexadecane (n-C16) with no carbon loss. Concurrently, these reactions are often accompanied by a small amount of oxygen-containing intermediates, hexadecanal (C15H31CHO), hexadecanol (C16H33OH), and palmityl palmitate (C15H31COOC16H33). Subsequently, it is anticipated that the n-C15 and n-C16 alkanes formed through deoxygenation will undergo hydroisomerization via a synergistic catalysis between the metal and acid sites on the bifunctional catalyst [20,27,53]. A typical chromatogram for the deoxygenation-hydroisomerization reaction of C15H31COOH in this work is presented in Fig. S4 , comprising cracking products (C4-C14), pentadecane and iso-pentadecanes (n-C15 and iso-C15), hexadecane and iso-hexadecanes (n-C16 and iso-C16), as well as a small amount of deoxygenation intermediates, including C16H33OH, palmityl palmitate (C15H31COOC16H33), and palmitone (C15H31COC15H31). It is interesting that the intermediate C15H31COC15H31 was formed over the ZSM-22 supported-Ni catalyst in the presence of H2 atmosphere. Fig. 8 illustrates the conversion of C15H31COOH over the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalysts as a function of the reaction temperature. All the catalysts exhibited a similar trend, with C15H31COOH conversion increasing as the reaction temperature rose. The 0.5Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst demonstrated the lowest C15H31COOH conversion among these catalysts, which were attributed to its limited number of metal sites due to the very low Ni loading. Previous studies suggested that the fatty acids conversion primarily occurred via C-O cleavage on the metal active sites [7,8,15]. The 0.5Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst had only 31 μmol/g of accessible Ni active sites (Table 4), much fewer than the xNi/N-ZSM-22 catalysts with higher Ni loadings (x = 1.0–6.0). While increasing the reaction temperature from 250°C to 290 °C resulted in a slight change in the C15H31COOH conversion, a significant difference in the iso-alkanes selectivity over these catalysts was observed. Fig. 9 displays the total iso-alkanes selectivity (iso-C15 + iso-C16) of the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalysts as a function of reaction temperature. The iso-alkanes (iso-C16 and iso-C15) are almost undetectable at the low C15H31COOH conversion. However, iso-alkanes selectivity (iso-C16 and iso-C15) increased substantially upon achieving complete C15H31COOH conversion. A possible reaction pathway is as follows: (1) the oxygen in the C15H31COOH absorbed on the xNi/N-ZSM-22 catalyst is removed on the Ni active sites to produce long-chain n-C15 and n-C16 alkanes via hydrodeoxygenation and decarbonylation/decarboxylation pathways; (2) subsequently, the formed long-chain n-C15 and n-C16 alkanes undergo dehydrogenation, isomerization, and hydrogenation to form iso-alkanes through a pore-mouth reaction mechanism involving the synergistic interaction between the Ni sites and acid sites. Thus, the Ni active sites are responsible for both C15H31COOH deoxygenation and dehydrogenation/hydrogenation steps that converted the formed n-alkanes into iso-alkanes. The iso-alkanes selectivity underwent a significant change with increasing Ni loading. Overall, as the Ni loading increased, the total iso-alkanes selectivity initially increased and then decreased at the selected reaction temperature, exhibiting a volcanic-like shape. It was noted that the iso-alkanes selectivity remained low, even with high C15H31COOH conversion. For example, the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst achieved a C15H31COOH conversion exceeding 80 % at 240 °C, yet the iso-alkanes selectivity was only 49.1 %. This observation suggests that C15H31COOH deoxygenation proceeds faster than n-alkane hydroisomerization, implying that the deoxygenation of C15H31COOH is favored when C15H31COOH and n-alkanes compete for adsorption on Ni active sites. Consequently, a higher reaction temperature is needed to optimize iso-alkanes selectivity through the combined action of Ni and acid sites. The optimal iso-alkane selectivity was achieved with the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst (81.8 %, Fig. 9), much higher than that the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst (58.4 %). As a result, the accessible Ni active sites in the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalysts plays a critical role in C15H31COOH deoxygenation, and the synergistic interaction between Ni and acid sites is essential for achieving high iso-alkanes selectivity. In addition, a comparison of the deoxygenation-hydroisomerization performance between the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 and the other catalysts reported in literatures was listed in Table 5 . These catalytic data indicated that the Ni catalyst on N-ZSM-22 showed superior isomerization selectivity compared to the reported transition metal catalysts (Ni and Co) on zeolites with 10-member ring pore structure, and even outperformed supported Pt catalysts. These results suggest that the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 exhibits excellent coupling catalytic performance for the deoxygenation and hydroisomerization reactions, implying the significant advantage of the N-ZSM-22 supported Ni catalyst for converting fatty acids into iso-alkanes in a single step. Fig. 10 presents the product distribution over these xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalysts, using the catalytic data obtained at 240 °C as an example. Notably, it was found that significant differences were observed in the product distributions of these catalysts. Pentadecanes (n-C15 and iso-C15) and hexadecanes (n-C16 and iso-C16) predominate in the liquid products over these xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) catalysts, with a small amount of intermediates and cracking products also present. This result suggests that the Ni catalyst on acidic nanocrystal ZSM-22 has good deoxygenation ability for C15H31COOH. The production of green biofuels from fatty acids deoxygenation over the Ni-based catalyst has been extensively reviewed by Prapainainar et. al. [22]. For comparison, the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst exhibits lower alkanes selectivity and higher selectivity for cracking products (16.3 %) and oxygen-containing intermediates (19.7 %) compared to the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst (3.7 and 3.8 %), demonstrating the strong cracking ability and poor catalytic deoxygenation activity of the conventional ZSM-22 supported Ni catalyst. This was because that the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 had lower external surface area (20 m2/g, Table 1) and less accessible Ni active sites (77.5 μmol/g, Table 4) than the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst (130 m2/g and 95.9 μmol/g), with a limitation of the diffusion rate of products and the hydrogenation ability for the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst. Furthermore, to elucidate the different catalytic performance over the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6) and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalysts, the intrinsic catalytic activity were further assessed at 270 °C after ruling out the mass transfer limitations by C WP and C M criteria. The obtained r obs and TOF are presented in Table 6 . The r obs and TOF for the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 (13.6 × 10−4 mol·g−1·h−1 and 14.2 h−1) are the highest among these xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6) and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22catalysts, which can be related to the synergism catalysis between available Ni active sites and external acid sites. Finally, the catalytic stability of the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst was evaluated and presented in Fig. 11 . The C15H31COOH conversion maintained ∼ 9.0 % after stabilization period. But the total selectivity for the n-C16 and n-C15 showed a significant decrease at the initial reaction period, and then kept at ∼ 23 %. Then, the spent 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst was analyzed by TG analysis, as shown in Fig. S5 . The weight loss observed below 200 °C, between 200–450 °C, and above 450 °C was attributed to physically adsorbed H2O, coke precursors, and coke formed on the spent catalyst, respectively [59,60]. both fresh and spent 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalysts exhibited a minor and similar weight loss below 100 °C, likely due to H2O. Notably, the spent catalyst exhibited a significant weight loss of 1.8 wt% in temperature range of 250–450 °C, indicating the formation of coke precursors during the reaction [59,60]. Previous studies have reported that the carbonaceous species deposited on the Ni(Co)/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are the primary cause of catalyst deactivation [61]. Therefore, the reduced deoxygenation activity observed for the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalysts is likely due to the deposition of coke precursors on the surface, which blocks oxygenated intermediates from accessing the active sites. To assess the mass balance, the number of carbon atoms in the final product solution was estimated to be 15.5 mmol, a little lower than the expected 16.4 mmol, corresponding to the hourly C15H31COOH feed rate. Consequently, the calculated mass balance was 94.5 %. The observed carbon loss can be attributed to the formed CO/CO2 in the exhaust gas, as well as the coke formation on the catalyst surface supported by the TG analysis of the spent catalyst. Additionally the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst was evaluated using a reaction liquid comprising 5.0 wt% triglycerides in cyclohexane, and the resulting data are presented in Fig. S6 . The results indicate that the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst exhibits excellent deoxygenation ability, yielding over 99.0 % of C15-C18 alkanes. Concurrently, the products contain substantial amounts of C15-C18 iso-alkanes, with a yield of approximately 51 %. Additionally, the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst demonstrates good stability throughout the testing period. Further research will be conducted to optimize the iso-alkanes yield to the maximum extent. These results suggest that the nanocrystal N-ZSM-22 zeolite-supported Ni catalyst holds great promise for converting triglycerides into high-value alkanes in a single step. 3.3 Unveiling deoxygenation pathway To elucidate the reaction pathway for the deoxygenation and hydroisomerization of the C15H31COOH, the conversion of C15H31COOH was controlled from approximately 10 % to 99 % by adjusting the catalyst weight or WHSV (1.6–9.1 h−1). Fig. 12 illustrates the selectivity of the main products as a function of C15H31COOH conversion on the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst. The results show that the total selectivity of the deoxygenated products, C15 and C16, increases with increasing C15H31COOH conversion. Only a little amount of n-C15 and C15H31CHO were detected at C15H31COOH conversion below 20 %。Notably, in addition to the typical intermediate products, such as C15H31CHO, C16H33OH, and C15H31COOC16H33, it was surprisingly found that significant amounts of pentacene (C15H30) and C15H31COC15H31 were detected at C15H31COOH conversion below 20 %. These unusual intermediate products accounted for up to 27.4 % and 40.2 % of the total products, respectively. A representative chromatogram data, accompanied by the corresponding mass spectra, is presented in Fig. S7- 13. The mass analysis confirmed that the peaks with retention times of 12.644–12.791 min and 27.964 min correspond to the C15H30 and C15H31COC15H31, respectively. The presence of these intermediate products suggests that the reaction pathway is more complex than that reported in the literatures [15,62–64], involving unexpected reactions and transformations. As the conversion of C15H31COC15H31 increased, the selectivities toward C15H30 and C15H31COC15H31 experienced a sharp decline. This phenomenon was attributed to the extended contact time, which favored the further reactions. Consequently, the unsaturated C15H30 was converted to saturated pentadecanes, including n- and iso-pentadecanes. To study the C15H30 formation, catalytic experiments were performed using the C15H31CHO, C16H33OH, and C15H31COC15H31 as reactants over the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst in the presence of H2. Reactant conversions was maintained at approximately 20 %, and the product distributions wereanalyzed and listed in Table S1 . C15H31CHO conversion yielded significant amounts of n-C15H32 (48.1 %). C15H31COC15H31 conversion primarily produced hentriacontane (C31H64, 72.6 %) and C15H32 (6.0 %), while C16H33OH conversion yielded mainly n-C16H34 (61.6 %). Trace amounts of C15H30 (1.4 % and 0.9 %, respectively, in the C15H31CHO and C15H31COC15H31 reactions) were detected. Only CO was detected in the exhaust gas from both reactions. Furthermore, the catalytic experiment for C15H31COOH conversion was also carried out on the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst in the presence of N2, and the product distribution in Table S1 showed that the selectivity to C15H30 was as high as 34.1 %, higher than that of 27.4 % in the presence of H2. These results above suggest that C15H30 formation may result from the direct deoxygenation of C15H31COOH, producing CO and H2O. Similar catalytic results have been reported by Fu [65] and Zhao et al [62]. Based on the results above and the reported literatures [15,63,64], the reaction pathway for the deoxygenation and hydroisomerization of the C15H31COOH was proposed in Scheme 1 . As illustrated in Scheme 1, the C15H31COOH underwent deoxygenation over the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst via three parallel reaction pathways: (i) direct deoxygenation to give unsaturated C15H30 with O removal in the form of CO and H2O, followed by hydrogenation or hydroisomerization to form C15H32; (ii) ketonization between two C15H31COOH molecules to give C15H31COC15H31 with the O removal in the form of H2O and CO2, followed by deoxygenation to generate C15H32 and CO; (iii) first hydrogenation to give C15H31CHO with one O removal in the form of H2O, which was followed by decarbonylation to form C15H32 with another O removal in the form of CO, or hydrogenation to give C15H31CH2OH. Subsequently, the C15H31CH2OH further reacted to generate C16 alkanes through a dehydration-hydrogenation reaction. To elucidate deoxygenation pathway, a preliminary kinetic analysis was further conducted on the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst at 270 °C using a fixed-bed reactor in the absence of mass transfer limitations. Based on the reaction pathway outlined in Scheme 1 and the products distribution, a simplified reaction network is depicted in Fig. S14 . A series of differential equations were used to describe the variation of C15H31COOH and products distribution over the reaction time, which were presented in the supporting information , and were solved using the Runge-Kutta-Fehlberg (RKF) method. For comparison, the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst was also evaluated at the same reaction conditions. Fig. S15 displays the resulting fitting curves for the deoxygenation and hydroisomerization reaction over the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalysts, showing a good fitting with the experimental data. This suggested the deoxygenation reaction of C15H31COOH via the proposed reaction pathway. The obtained rate constants are listed in Table 7 . The formation of C15H31COC15H31 exhibited the highest reaction rate constant on the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst (6.30 and 5.0 h−1) among the reactions contributing to C15H31COOH conversion, indicating that ketone formation is the primary pathway. The 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst (k 1 + k 2 + k 3, 6.47 h−1) demonstrated a significantly higher reaction rate for C15H31COOH compared to the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst (k 1 + k 2 + k 3, 5.12 h−1). The apparent activation energy was calculated using Arrhenius equation, as plotted in Fig. S16 . It revealed that the apparent activation energy for C15H31COOH conversion was 103.6 kJ/mol·on the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst, lower than that on the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst (93.7 kJ/mol). The kinetic data indicated the benefits of using N-ZSM-22 as a support, primarily attributed to its porous structure. Furthermore, the iso-alkanes (iso-C15 and iso-C16) were almost undetectable at low C15H31COOH conversion, indicating that the deoxygenation-hydroisomerization reaction for C15H31COOH occurs in a successive manner. As the residence time or reaction temperature increases, the formed intermediates can be converted into desired isomers under the synergy of acid sites and metal sites over the N-ZSM-22 supported Ni catalyst. 3.4 Discussion on boosting isomerization selectivity for Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst It has been reported that the metal sites (Ru, Pt, Pd, and Ni) are responsible for the cleavage of C-O and C–C bonds for the C15H31COOH deoxygenation, resulting in the formation of n-alkanes with and without carbon atom loss, respectively [18,19,47]. In contrast, the hydroisomerization of long-chain n-alkanes occurs on bifunctional metal-loaded zeolite catalyst with metal/acid sites, where the metal sites (Pd, Pt, and Ni) promote dehydrogenation-hydrogenation and the acid sites (B acid) at the 10-MR openings of the zeolites (ZSM-22, ZSM-23, and SAPO-11) enable the formation of carbenium ions, followed by skeletal rearrangement [27]. Notably, increasing the number of accessible 10-MR openings in the used zeolite can enhance its isomerization selectivity, according to the pore mouth catalysis mechanism [31,33]. Therefore, the remarkable long-chain alkanes isomerization selectivity of the Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst can be attributed to its porous architecture and the balance of metal–acid functions in this catalyst. In this work, the N-ZSM-22 exhibits shorter nanorods and more structural defects compared to the C-ZSM-22 (Figs. 2 and S2 ), consistent with the N2 adsorption results. After loading of Ni species, the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst retained a larger external surface area (130 m2/g) and mesoporous volume (0.65 cm3/g) compared to the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst (20 m2/g and 0.10 cm3/g). In this case, this porous structure of the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst could facilitate higher diffusion efficiency for reactants compared to that of the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst, thereby avoiding cracking reaction. More importantly, the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst had more accessible 10-MR openings than the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst, as confirmed by the DMPy-IR results (Fig. 6 b), demonstrating that the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst exhibited more B sites than the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 catalyst (20.8 vs 12.2 μmol/g) at the pore mouth and external surface. The increased number of 10-MR openings in the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst facilitates the insertion and immediate adsorption of the long-chain n-alkanes in the 10-MR channel, enhancing the protonation and skeletal branching at the B acidic sites of the 10-MR openings. This explains why the two catalysts, 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22, showed similar deoxygenation abilities for the C15H31COOH, but differed significantly in their iso-alkanes (iso-C15 and iso-C16) selectivity (81.8 % vs 58.4 %). Additionally, the elevated CNi/CH+ ratio observed for 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 relative to 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 (6.3 versus 4.6) is indicative of a weaker acid functionality in the former catalyst. This suggests that accessible B acid sites on 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 is insufficient to effectively catalyze the isomerization of iso-olefin intermediates. Furthermore, the enhanced diffusion limitations within the 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 lead to cracking reaction, thereby accounting for the observed higher cracking selectivity of 24.0 %, as compared to 10.5 % for the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22. On the other hand, the Ni species serve as the active sites that not only undertake the deoxygenation of C15H31COOH, but also catalyze the dehydrogenation/hydrogenation reactions that transform the formed n-alkanes into iso-alkanes. Therefore, the number of accessible Ni sites is closely linked to the C15H31COOH conversion and the selectivity of iso-alkanes. As can be seen in Fig. 8, the 0.5Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst exhibited the lowest C15H31COOH conversion at 240 °C among the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5, 1.0, 3.0, and 6.0) catalysts, which is attributed to its fewer accessible active sites (31.0 μ mol/g). This limited the adsorption of carboxylic group in the fatty acid on the Ni active surface, thereby hindering the removal of oxygen. In contrast, increasing the Ni loading led to no significant difference in the C15H31COOH conversion among these xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 1.0, 3.0, and 6.0) catalysts, suggesting that the number of active Ni sites is sufficient to convert the C15H31COOH when the Ni loading exceeds 1.0 wt%. Additionally, elevating the reaction temperature did not significantly influence the C15H31COOH conversion among these xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5, 1.0, 3.0, and 6.0) catalysts, which may be due to the fact that the high reaction temperature compensated for the lack of metal functionality of the Ni species for the 0.5Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst. Of particular note is on attaining high long-chain iso-alkanes selectivity during C15H31COOH conversion, which involves the synergistic effect of acid sites and Ni sites. The balance between Ni sites and acid sites strongly influences the isomers selectivity, which is usually indexed by the CNi/CH +[53]. As shown in Table 4, the CNi/CH+ ratio for these xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) catalysts increases with Ni loading, because the increased loading provides more Ni active sites while simultaneously reducing the number of external surface acid sites. The CNi/CH+ ratio versus iso-alkanes selectivity is plotted in Fig. S17 . The much lower iso-alkanes selectivity for the 0.5Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst was attributed to its insufficient accessible Ni sites that mismatched with its acid function. As the Ni loading increases, the Ni sites and acid sites are gradually approaching balance, leading to an increase in iso-alkanes selectivity. The iso-alkanes selectivity increases with increasing CNi/CH + ratio on these xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–3.0) catalysts, achieving the maximum long-chain iso-alkanes selectivity on the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 at 270 °C. This suggests that the metal–acid balance is achieved with the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 for the conversion of C15H31COOH through the deoxygenation-hydroisomerization reaction. However, further increasing the Ni loading to 6.0 % results in a decrease in iso-alkanes selectivity. This decline can be attributed to high Ni loading blocking the pore mouths of the N-ZSM-22, thereby reducing the number of accessible 10-MR openings. This hypothesis is supported by the significant decrease in micropore volume and accessible acid sites at the external surface among the xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5–6.0) catalysts. In summary, these results demonstrate that the Ni catalyst on the N-ZSM-22 is a promising bifunctional catalyst for converting fatty acids into high-valued long-chain iso-alkanes components. 4 Conclusion Ni catalyst on N-ZSM-22 (Ni/N-ZSM-22) zeolite, characterized by numerous accessible 10-membered ring (10-MR) openings and an abundance of mesoporous structures, was developed for the one-step conversion of palmitic acid via deoxygenation and hydroisomerization reactions. The effect of Ni loading on the catalytic performance of xNi/N-ZSM-22 (x = 0.5, 1.0, 3.0, and 6.0) catalysts was investigated. The results suggested that the hydroisomerization performance was more influenced by Ni loading than deoxygenation performance, which could be attributed to the metal–acid function balance in the xNi/N-ZSM-22 catalysts. The activity data revealed that the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 catalyst exhibited the optimal iso-alkanes selectivity among these xNi/N-ZSM-22 catalysts, significantly outperforming a Ni catalyst on conventional ZSM-22 (3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22), which had a selectivity of only 58.4 %. A comparison between the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 and 3.0Ni/C-ZSM-22 demonstrated the advantages of the more accessible 10-MR openings and the abundant mesoporous structure in facilitating the catalytic conversion of deoxygenation and hydroisomerization in a single step. Ketonization of palmitic acid plays an important role in the initial deoxygenation stage of palmitic acid conversion. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic conversion of biomass-derived fatty acids into iso-alkanes is a promising approach for producing high-quality renewable biofuels. Herein, Ni catalysts on nanocrystal ZSM-22 (xNi/N-ZSM-22, x represents Ni loading) featuring an abundance of mesoporous structure and numerous accessible 10-member ring (10-MR) openings are prepared, and then tested for converting palmitic acid into long-chain iso-alkanes through a single-step process involving deoxygenation and hydroisomerization reactions. The catalyst with a Ni loading of 3.0 wt% (3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22) demonstrated the highest intrinsic reaction rate (13.6 × 10−4 mol·g−1·h−1) and TOF (14.2 h−1) among xNi/N-ZSM-22 catalysts. This catalyst also exhibited optimal iso-alkanes selectivity of 81.8 % (iso-hexadecanes and iso-pentadecanes), which can be attributed to the efficient synergy between the acid and metal functions. In comparison to a Ni catalyst on conventional ZSM-22 (58.4 %), the superior isomerization selectivity (81.8 %) of the 3.0Ni/N-ZSM-22 is closely related to its abundant mesoporous structure and more accessible 10-MR openings. Moreover, ketonization was identified as a significant pathway for palmitic acid deoxygenation based on kinetic analysis.
